Hilbert spaces and their linear functions play a central role in quantum theory. We show that the category of Hilbert spaces and their linear operators is equivalent to the category of complete atomic Boolean algebras and their continuous functions. This resolves a question raised by von Neumann, Mackey, and others. The proof is purely categorical. It may be of independent interest.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species and a cnidarian species. Our results suggest that the Myxozoa are a sister group to the cnidarian parasite Polypodium hydriforme and that the myxozoan body plan was derived from a cnidarian. Our findings also suggest that the Myxozoa are one of the most reduced animal lineages. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic that has caused millions of deaths worldwide. The SARS-CoV-2 virus is able to evade the host immune response by blocking IFN signaling. In this study, we identified a viral accessory protein, Orf6, that is able to block nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2. We found that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and interacts with Nup98-Rae1. This interaction is required for Orf6 to block nuclear import. Our results unveil a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Our findings may help to design new antiviral strategies against SARS-CoV-2. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. However, the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1 is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. Our findings provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Climate change is expected to increase the variability of crop yields. This study quantifies the impact of global warming on the variability of maize yields in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that the variability of maize yields will increase everywhere in the world. The increase is larger in countries that export maize. The probability that a country has simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results highlight the need for investments in breeding maize varieties that are better adapted to a warmer world. This is especially urgent in countries that export maize. The coexistence of many species of large herbivores in the same ecosystem is a major puzzle in ecology. One hypothesis is that species partition food resources. However, the extent to which species do so is unknown because it is difficult to identify species-level differences in diet. We used DNA metabarcoding to identify plant species consumed by seven species of large herbivores in a semiarid African savanna. We found that species differed in the proportion of their diet made up of grasses, and that this proportion was correlated with isotopic estimates of the proportion of grass in their diet. We also found that species differed in the proportion of their diet made up of grasses, and that this proportion was correlated with isotopic estimates of the proportion of grass in their diet. Nonetheless, species did not overlap in their diets. These results suggest that species may partition food resources, but only to a limited extent. Our results also suggest that the coexistence of many species of large herbivores may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This article is protected by copyright. COVID-19 has had a devastating impact on small businesses. We surveyed more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Many businesses are financially fragile, with only a few weeks of cash on hand. Finally, many businesses expect the crisis to last for many months.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread environmental problems of our time. However, the global scale of the problem is still unknown. We show that the plastic debris on the surface of the open ocean is mostly concentrated in convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres. However, the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface was estimated to be on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of plastic debris by the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. This study is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The origin of silicon carbide grains is still a matter of debate. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma. A majority of the grains have ages of <1 Ga. The grains were part of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium. The grains were exposed to a low cosmic ray flux of the early active sun.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950. This expansion has been driven by the motorized fleet, particularly the powered-artisanal fleet. The powered-artisanal fleet is the most numerous and the most important in terms of engine power. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased since 1950, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of the global fleet has decreased by 50% since 1950. The global fleet is stabilizing, but the rate of expansion is slowing. The powered-artisanal fleet is the most vulnerable to overexploitation.

The ability to reproduce is the most fundamental characteristic of life. In this study, we show that the ability to reproduce is also the most plastic. We find that the reproductive output of mammals is strongly correlated with the amount of energy available to the mother. This energy is not only from the mother’s own body, but also from the body of the mother’s caretakers. We find that the more caretakers a mother has, the more she can reproduce. This effect is not due to resource availability, but rather to the metabolic power of the mother. Our results suggest that the ability to reproduce is the most limiting factor in the evolution of placental mammals. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder. The cytopathological hallmark of MSA is the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the progressive toxicity of α-syn aggregation in a mouse model of MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn and with neuroprotective effects. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels. It is the most abundant cell type in the body and is responsible for many of the most important functions of the cardiovascular system. The endothelium is able to control many of the most important physiological processes, including blood pressure, inflammation, and hemostasis. The endothelium is able to control these functions by receiving and integrating information from multiple sources. Here, we describe the nature of the communication network between endothelial cells. The network is surprisingly small-world, which means that it is both efficient at local and global communication. This design is effective for controlling the cardiovascular system.

COVID-19 has been a global pandemic for over a year. The pandemic has been accompanied by a large body of research, policy, and public health activity. However, there is a need for data that can be used to track the pandemic and its impact on society. We present a data source that provides a comprehensive view of the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled. The selectivity filter is closed in the inactive state and opens upon channel activation. This process is coupled to the opening of the activation gate. However, the mechanism of this coupling is not fully understood. Here we provide evidence that the selectivity filter is allosterically coupled to the activation gate. This allosteric communication is essential for the proper functioning of potassium channels.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical for health. The majority of the microbiome resides in the digestive tract of animals, including humans. The composition of the gut microbiome is influenced by the host and the diet. The host can influence the microbiome composition by changing the diet. The microbiome can also influence the host. For example, the microbiome can influence the host’s health and disease. The host can also influence the microbiome. For example, the host can alter the microbiome composition by changing the diet. Here, we show that anaerobic fungi in the gut of herbivores can influence the composition of the microbiome. These fungi can also produce natural products that could be used as therapeutics.

Anxiety is a common feature of psychiatric disorders. However, the mechanisms underlying social anxiety remain largely unknown. Here we show that high-anxious rats are prone to become subordinate in a social encounter with a low-anxious rat. We further demonstrate that this low probability to become dominant is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. These findings suggest that brain energy metabolism is crucial for social behavior and may be a potential target for the treatment of anxiety-related social disorders. The design of multifunctional structures with desired mechanical responses is of great importance for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties into composite structures. The structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The synthesized structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and heteroassembly. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein in red blood cells. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human red blood cells is regulated by a complex network of transcription factors and miRNAs. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a downstream element of the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 is developmentally downregulated in human red blood cells and that its overexpression in erythroid cells results in a nearly complete reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern. This suggests a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. Our findings may have implications for the development of hemoglobinopathies and hemoglobin-based therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is a major cause of death worldwide. The development of cancer is associated with the accumulation of mutations in the genome and in signaling pathways. In this study, we found that cancer cells with mutations in the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway are resistant to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is associated with activation of the mTORC1 signaling pathway and induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. We also found that SREBP1 mediates ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells through induction of stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), a transcriptional target of SREBP1 that produces monounsaturated fatty acids. These findings suggest that mTORC1 inhibition may sensitize cancer cells to ferroptosis induction, and that combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. This strategy may be applicable to a wide range of cancers with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutations. (Read more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is a major challenge for the medical community. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. These drugs are effective but have side effects. We show that calcium channel blockers activate a store-operated Ca2+ entry pathway that is important for the development of vascular remodeling. Our findings may lead to the development of new drugs with fewer side effects. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity in the Pacific Northwest. It was science-based, incorporated adaptive management, and was the first to require the monitoring of biodiversity. We show that the NWFP has not been successful in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. The policy has been effective in halting clearcutting on federal land, but this has so far been insufficient to reverse declines in older-forest–associated bird populations. The NWFP has not been effective in halting the decline of older forests or in reversing the decline of early-seral–associated bird populations.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is urgently needed. Here, we present a rational design strategy for the development of new acylide antibiotics. The strategy is based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. We show that the best compounds designed by us are active against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. This strategy can be applied to the development of new antibiotics for other classes of antibiotics. Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The network architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales. The resulting network is easy to implement, train, and apply in practice.

The evolution of the African Great Lakes is a key process in the development of the continent and its biota. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability from Lake Malawi. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Our results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after the MPT. Our results suggest that the evolution of the African Great Lakes is a response to orbital forcing and that the MPT is a critical time in the evolution of the continent. The extreme hydroclimate variability exerted a profound influence on the Lake Malawi endemic cichlid fish species flock; the geographically extensive habitat reconfiguration provided novel ecological opportunities, enabling new populations to differentiate rapidly to distinct species

The use of electronic devices before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. However, the biological effects of such technology use on sleep are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device before bedtime phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and reduces the next-morning alertness. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Younger Dryas cooling is attributed to a bolide impact. However, the bolide impact hypothesis is controversial. We show that the osmium isotopic composition of the Younger Dryas sediments is consistent with a terrestrial origin. The spherules from the same site are also consistent with a terrestrial origin. These results support the impact hypothesis.

CTLA-4 is a well-known negative regulator of T cell activation. However, its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is not fully understood. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice. We also show that CTLA-4 deficiency has opposing effects on different autoimmune models. Thus, CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance. Our findings have important implications for the treatment of autoimmune diseases. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals. However, the evolutionary history of beetles remains poorly understood. Here, we present a comprehensive analysis of the phylogeny and diversification of beetles. We show that beetles diversified in the presence of angiosperms and that the evolution of specialized plant feeding was driven by the acquisition of genes encoding enzymes that degrade plant cell walls. Our results suggest that beetles diversified in a relatively stable environment, allowing for the evolution of a large number of specialized plant feeders. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been a global health crisis. The development of effective vaccines and therapeutic antibodies is critical to combat the pandemic. However, the emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the efficacy of these antibodies. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach to optimize the binding affinity of antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody that is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. Our optimized antibody can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our approach can be applied to other protein molecules. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of technology is a central theme in human evolution. We report a large-scale experiment that investigates the role of population size in the evolution of technology. We find that larger populations do not enhance the performance of technology. This finding is important because it suggests that the evolution of technology may be limited by the size of the population.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is the APOE genotype. APOE is a lipid-binding protein. APOE4 is associated with a twofold increased risk for AD, whereas APOE2 is associated with a twofold decreased risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. We also found that APOE alleles affect the accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain. These studies suggest a hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with AD risk in part because of defective astrocytic phagocytic capacity, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses. This hypothesis may help to explain the complex relationship between APOE and AD risk. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km. It is the densest part of the planet. The formation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. The required degree of undercooling to nucleate the inner core is a key factor in solving the paradox. We found that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase is much easier than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the paradox. Our results also suggest that the inner core is not made of a single homogeneous phase. Instead, it is composed of two phases with different crystal structures. This is consistent with the seismic anisotropy of the inner core. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Marijuana is the most widely used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability. These findings suggest that chronic marijuana use is associated with decreased brain reactivity to DA stimulation. This decreased reactivity might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors associated with marijuana use. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Language is the defining cognitive ability of the human species. How the human brain processes language is therefore a central question in cognitive neuroscience. Here, we show that the most accurate artificial neural networks that predict brain activity during language processing are also the most accurate predictors of subsequent word production. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. The approach we present here can be applied to any domain in which brain activity can be measured with imaging techniques. It thus has the potential to revolutionize the field. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep learning is a powerful machine learning paradigm that has been successful in many applications. However, it is still in its infancy and faces many challenges. One of the most fundamental challenges is the instability of deep learning algorithms. In this paper, we show that this instability is closely related to the difficulty of training algorithms. We prove that there are well-conditioned problems in scientific computing where no training algorithm can find a stable solution. This result provides a classification theory of the conditions under which stable solutions can be found. Our results have implications for the development of deep learning algorithms. They also suggest new research directions in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a unique opportunity to reflect on the nature of science and its role in society. This article is a critical examination of a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. It is a cautionary tale of researchers falling prey to their own research.

Leprosy is a chronic disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae. The pathogen has undergone extensive reductive evolution, and the genome of the only cultured strain, M. leprae, is 10 times smaller than that of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Here we report the genome sequence of a second leprosy pathogen, M. lepromatosis, which is associated with a different clinical form of the disease. The two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. Our findings suggest that the two leprosy pathogens have been in a long-term evolutionary relationship. Copyright © 2014. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the keystones of quantum information science. The interplay between them is still not fully understood. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems can be fully described in the scaling limit of infinite system length. This result is obtained by combining integrability with a quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics. Our findings open the door to the study of entanglement in interacting systems.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has caused millions of deaths worldwide. The development of a vaccine is the only way to control the pandemic. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine candidate. The vaccine candidate is temperature sensitive in vitro, but grows robustly at the permissive temperature. The vaccine candidate is protective in hamsters. The vaccine candidate is easy to manufacture on a large scale. These features make the vaccine candidate a promising candidate for use in mass vaccination programs. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. The Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during the Second Pandemic is still debated. Here, we show that human ectoparasites, such as fleas, were the primary vector of plague. This contradicts the assumption that plague was predominantly spread by rats. Our results have implications for our understanding of the history of plague and its control. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known story. However, the evolution of brain neuronal density is not. We present a comprehensive dataset of neuron numbers in amniotes and use it to reconstruct the evolution of brain neuronal density. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be a tumor suppressor. However, its function in mitochondria of normal cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. This study provides a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the actin cytoskeleton. It is involved in many cellular processes, including cell motility and cell division. However, the mechanism by which ADF regulates actin dynamics is not fully understood. Here, we show that ADF can induce torque on actin filaments. This torque is enhanced when the filaments are held between two anchoring points. We propose that this mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings provide a mechanism for understanding ADF’s function in cells. They also provide a platform for developing new strategies for controlling the actin cytoskeleton. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Fructose is the most common sweetener in the Western diet. It is a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in reward-related regions and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may promote feeding behavior. Understanding the effects of sweeteners on brain and behavior may help explain the high prevalence of obesity in the Western world. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals. The recent history of Madagascar is revealed by the distribution of African and Asian ancestry. The settlement of Madagascar was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across the island. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This constitutes experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. Our results suggest that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

The ribosome is a molecular machine that reads messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences and translates them into proteins. The mRNA sequences that direct protein synthesis are not the only RNAs that are translated. Messenger RNA modifications can also influence protein synthesis. In this study, we show that the presence of a single pseudouridine (Ψ) in messenger RNA can modestly alter translation speed and the decoding of mRNA codons. Our findings suggest that the ribosome can encounter Ψ moieties and alter mRNA decoding. This study highlights the importance of mRNA modifications in the translation process. (Read more)

The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of health and behavioral outcomes. These associations are robust to a range of potential confounders and are maintained over time. The feeling that life is worthwhile may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. These findings have implications for public health and gerontology. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The evolution of body size is a central question in biology. Here, we show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in four of the five extant aquatic mammal lineages. This result is consistent with energetic constraints on the evolution of body size in the aquatic realm.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically costly diseases in the world. The rhinovirus is the main cause of the common cold. This study demonstrates that rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperature of the nasal cavity than at the core body temperature. This temperature-dependent growth phenotype is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings may help to develop new strategies for the treatment of the common cold. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Bacteria use a variety of sensors to respond to environmental signals. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its surface adhesin type IV pili to sense surfaces. This mechanosensory system is mediated by the Chp chemosensory system, a chemotaxis-like system that regulates the production of cAMP and transcription of hundreds of genes. The system is activated by the mechanical activity of type IV pili, which are stretched by the surface. The system is also amplified by a positive feedback loop that increases the activity of type IV pili. This mechanochemical model for surface sensing is unique among bacteria and may be important for understanding the evolution of this important pathogen. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades. However, the consequences of this development on the quality of surface waters are not well understood. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on human health and the global economy. The virus has also spread to animals, including deer, and may persist in wildlife. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living deer. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. We call for a more comprehensive and coordinated approach to monitor and mitigate the impact of the virus in both humans and animals. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Hydropower is the leading source of renewable energy. It is also the leading cause of environmental destruction. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. It is currently incurable and has no known cure. The disease is associated with a chronic state of inflammation. The immune response in AD is thought to be driven by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) plaques and neurodegeneration. However, we show that Aβ is not the only toxic species in AD. We demonstrate that neurons are burdened with increasing levels of Aβ and are the source of a unique inflammatory response. Our findings suggest that the accumulation of Aβ in neurons may be a significant contributor to the AD pathogenesis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread and important domesticated species in the world. However, its history is still largely unknown. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. This is a significant finding, as it provides evidence for the earliest use of this species for economic purposes. Our survey of the Southern Levant shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. This is a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of proteins is a complex process. It is not yet clear how many distinct intermediates are involved. Here we report the results of a study of the folding of maltose binding protein. We show that the folding process is multistep and that the intermediates are distinct. This is a significant advance in our understanding of protein folding.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism for bacterial adaptation. However, the cellular response to this stress is not well understood. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to dephosphorylate the 5′ termini of transcripts, also deprotects dinucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) 5′ ends. This enzyme is the predominant decapping enzyme in proteobacteria when cells are experiencing disulfide stress. We show that this enzyme deprotects Np4-capped 5′ termini at a much higher rate than its canonical substrates. This differential impact on the rates at which capped and noncapped 5′ termini are deprotected could have major consequences for the reprogramming of gene expression during disulfide stress. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. Here we show that arginine, a key amino acid in the urea cycle, is depleted in sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a metabolite of arginine, is increased in sepsis. These findings suggest that arginine deprivation is a common mechanism involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis. Our results also suggest that citrulline could be used as a therapeutic strategy to restore immune function in sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results highlight the importance of the biomass of the biosphere for understanding the functioning of the ecosystem. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics that is characterized by the presence of a critical state, where the system is neither too active nor too passive. SOC is observed in a variety of systems, including sandpiles, earthquakes, fire spreading, and avalanches of various kinds. In this paper, we present a model of SOC that is continuous in contrast to all known models. Our model is a scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap and high hardness. It is used in many applications, including high-performance sensors and lasers. However, its properties can be improved. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain. This opens up new possibilities for tailoring its properties.

The discovery of antimicrobial peptides in plants is a recent and exciting development. However, the mode of action of these peptides is not fully understood. Here, we report the antifungal activity of a unique plant NCR peptide. This peptide is structurally and functionally distinct from other antimicrobial peptides. It is highly diverse and exhibits potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. It binds to multiple phosphoinositides in germlings, and induces cell death at the site of infection. This work provides a foundation for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the evolution of sex. However, the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm is largely unknown. Here, we use proteomics and isotopic labeling to characterize the posttesticular life history of Drosophila sperm. We show that sperm undergo substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. Most of these changes occur within the seminal fluid, suggesting that the male–female reproductive axis is a dynamic system. In addition, we show that female-derived proteins become associated with sperm immediately after mating and that these proteins support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets to promote blood clotting. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force can switch the VWF A1 domain to a second state with faster binding. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD. The force-switchable state is also present in the normal GPIbα receptor, which may explain the increased binding of platelets to the normal receptor under flow. This work provides a mechanism for the effects of VWD mutations on VWF binding to platelets. It also provides a mechanism for the effects of flow on platelet adhesion. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been much harder to study. This study provides a comprehensive resource for human-associated viruses. We find that viruses are associated with many diseases, including cancer, diabetes, and autism.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of ACI processes and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to overcome this conundrum. The HSRL is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties. We demonstrate the scientific potential of the HSRL to investigate ACI processes. The observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of debate for decades. Here we present a method for determining the temperature of the surface of the early Earth based on the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes. Our results suggest that the surface temperature of the early Earth was cooler than previously thought. This finding is consistent with both isotopic and protein reconstruction-based interpretations of the temperature history of the early Earth. These studies demonstrate the utility of integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data to provide new insights into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Ion channels are the main ion conduits in the body. They are also the main targets of drugs. Ion channels are regulated by multiple mechanisms. In this study, we found that the large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel has a unique mechanism of slow inactivation. This mechanism may be a common feature of other ion channels.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world. The Plasmodium parasite infects red blood cells, where it replicates and causes disease. The malaria parasite exploits the host cell to facilitate entry into the red blood cell. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the red blood cell to facilitate entry. This is a major change in our understanding of malaria parasite invasion. Our findings suggest that the malaria parasite primes the erythrocyte surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap and high hardness. It is used in many applications, including high-performance sensors and lasers. However, its properties can be improved. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain. This opens up new possibilities for tailoring its properties.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The seasonal outbreaks of influenza correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following influenza virus infection. We also show that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings may help to develop strategies to reduce the impact of influenza virus outbreaks. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. However, there is no direct evidence for this process in the brain. Here, we show that high-gamma power increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is applied equally to words and phrases, and it is consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up parser. Our results suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This process may be essential for language comprehension and production.

Axin is a key component of the Wnt signaling pathway. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are not only similar at the protein level but also genetically redundant. We also show that the two forms of Axin are differentially regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation may be used to control the tissue-specific response of the Wnt pathway.

Obesity is a major public health problem. The mechanisms that regulate food intake are not fully understood. Here we present a characterization of a brain circuit that may promote overeating. This circuit is located in the brain’s reward center, the lateral hypothalamus. We show that electrical stimulation of this region causes rapid vigorous eating in sated animals. We also show that this circuit is involved in overeating. This circuit may contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth. However, the nitrogenase enzyme that fixes atmospheric nitrogen is highly inefficient. Thus, the majority of nitrogen fixed by bacteria is in the form of dinitrogen, which is highly reactive and difficult to use by plants. We have developed a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This could be used to improve the nitrogen use efficiency of cereals and other crops. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest. It is also one of the most threatened. We study a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that was designed to reduce deforestation. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated. However, the effects are imprecisely estimated. The results suggest that community-based monitoring can contribute to sustainable forest management.

The ability to hear is fundamental to all animals. However, the auditory organs of animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. The spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads and remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave. The spider’s web is also flexible and regularly regenerated, allowing it to be adjusted and regularly renewed. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The health and climate impacts of air pollution are well known. However, the climate impacts of anthropogenic aerosols are less understood. We show that aerosols are responsible for 70% of the excess mortality from outdoor air pollution. This is a major contribution to the climate cooling. Our results suggest that aerosols and fossil-fuel-related emissions should be controlled simultaneously to achieve the 2 °C target.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic with no known cure. Vaccines are the only proven intervention. The current vaccines are based on the Wuhan-Hu-1 sequence of the spike protein. We engineered a new sequence variant of the spike protein that is well-suited for large-volume microbial manufacturing. The engineered protein exhibits high-affinity binding to ACE2, and antibodies raised against the engineered protein exhibit heterotypic binding to the variants of concern. Presentation of the engineered protein on a virus-like particle also reduced weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results suggest that the engineered protein may be a promising candidate for a future vaccine. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ALK family of receptors is implicated in a variety of human cancers. In the present study, we show that zebrafish ALK homologs are involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. Our results provide evidence that the ALK/ALKALS signaling pathway is involved in the regulation of neural crest development. This pathway may be a promising target for the development of new therapeutic strategies for neuroblastoma. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. The emergence of Yersinia pestis from its progenitor Yersinia pseudotuberculosis is a well-documented event, but the details of its evolution and ecology during this formative period are still largely unknown. Here, we present 17 genomes of Y. pestis from the Eurasian Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age period. Our results reveal a single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions. These data provide insights into the early evolution and ecology of plague. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—is associated with men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump. This finding is consistent with the idea that HM is a cultural ideology that legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies. The findings have implications for understanding the political climate in the United States and the world.

Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management of agricultural lands is often at odds with SOC sequestration. We show that soil health management practices can increase SOC storage on grassland-derived Mollisols. These practices include reduced tillage, diversified crop rotations with cover crops and legumes, and manure addition. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester SOC and highlight the importance of including perennial grasslands in climate-smart agriculture. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify host, viral, and environmental risk factors contributing to spillover and spread of viruses in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses. Using data from a virus discovery project, we ranked the spillover potential of 887 wildlife viruses. The top 12 were known zoonotic viruses. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. SpillOver is a resource for policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for reproduction. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators. However, the mechanisms underlying the evolution of nectar color are not well understood. Here, we identify a red pigment in the nectar of a blood-red plant. We show that this pigment is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify the enzymes responsible for the production of this pigment in the nectar of a second plant. Our findings suggest that the evolution of a red nectar is a convergent trait. This work provides insight into the evolution of a key trait in the plant–pollinator interaction. It also provides a new tool for the study of plant–pollinator interactions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The genetic history of Europe is a complex story of migrations and invasions. However, the genetic history of the population during the period of the Migration Period and the Early Middle Ages is largely unknown. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from southern Germany, dating mostly to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of the individuals is very heterogeneous, including signals of genetic ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. Our results suggest that the genetic history of Europe during the Early Middle Ages was more complex than previously thought. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is responsible for ∼36% fatality in infected patients. The virus is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. Here, we report that HKU4 and MERS-CoV share a common receptor, DPP4, but have different entry activities into human and bat cells. These results suggest that MERS-CoV has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. Our findings also suggest that bat coronaviruses pose a risk to human health because of their capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmission. Our findings are of great significance for understanding the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV and the evolution of coronaviruses. Copyright © 2016. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The global spread of infectious diseases is a major public health concern. In resource-scarce settings, such as Cambodia, the detection of emerging pathogens is often limited by laboratory capacity. We used a cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens. Our findings highlight the importance of coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. This can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template. In humans, pol δ is anchored to the proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) sliding clamp to form a holoenzyme. The stability of this complex is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. However, the stability of the human pol δ holoenzyme is unknown. Here, we report the results of unique kinetic assays that reveal that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results also suggest that the human pol δ holoenzyme is more dynamic than its yeast counterpart. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA. In this paper, we describe the first in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA. This polymerase is able to synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can amplify short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Urban change is a central topic in urban studies. However, the mechanisms of urban change are not well understood. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We then use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change. Our method can be used to study urban change in other cities and other countries. It can also be used to study the physical dynamics of other urban phenomena, such as the spread of urban blight. Our results provide a new perspective on urban change.

COVID-19 is a new disease. The pathogenesis is not clear. The clinical manifestations are diverse. The mortality is high. The treatment is not perfect. Tocilizumab is a drug that is widely used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. It can reduce the mortality of severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient for all organisms, but its excess is toxic. The mechanisms of copper homeostasis in fungi are not well understood. Here we report the existence of a xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus. Xanthocillin is a siderophore that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. The xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster is widespread in filamentous fungi, suggesting a role for this pathway in copper homeostasis and interactions with competing microbes. This study provides insight into the role of fungal natural products in copper homeostasis and the evolution of copper-binding siderophores in eukaryotes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The formation of silica polymorphs in sedimentary rocks is rare on Earth and on Mars. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater is significant. Tridymite is a high-temperature (>870 °C) SiO2 polymorph that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater is possibly due to the cogenetic detrital source from silicic volcanism in the vicinity of the crater. The diagenesis of the tridymite and associated silica-rich amorphous material is also consistent with the presence of aqueous fluids at the sediment source. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater is significant in terms of the potential for the formation of silica polymorphs in sedimentary rocks on other planets. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Frost is a major environmental stressor of plants and animals in the Northern Hemisphere. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is associated with the evolutionary strategies of trees. Our findings can help decision-makers to anticipate and mitigate the impact of frost on ecosystems and on the economy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this subset is not well understood. Here we show that Th17 cells can be divided into two subsets. One subset retains a Th17 phenotype and is required for the development of colitis. The other subset, which is deficient in IFN-γ, is dispensable for colitis development. These results indicate that Th17 cells can have two distinct functions in the pathogenesis of colitis. One is to directly induce a Th17 phenotype, and the other is to provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. This dual function of Th17 cells may be important for the development of inflammatory bowel disease. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different genetic causes and different clinical courses. There is a need for disease modeling to identify disease mechanisms and develop therapeutics. Here, we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living ALS patients. This will enable high-throughput drug screening to identify therapeutics for ALS. This method will also be useful for studying other neurodegenerative diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The gut microbiota is essential for the survival of many arthropod vectors. However, the mechanisms by which infectious agents influence the composition of the vector’s microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein in the tick Ixodes scapularis. This protein alters the composition of the tick’s gut microbiota, which in turn influences the ability of the pathogen to colonize the tick. Our findings reveal a mechanism by which a human pathogen can influence the composition of the vector’s microbiota to enhance colonization. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the evolution of birds. The short-tailed bird group is a major evolutionary lineage that includes modern birds. However, the diversity of early members of this group is limited. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This discovery increases the known diversity of early members of the short-tailed bird group and adds important information about the evolution of the avian tail.

The climate system is very complex. It is therefore difficult to estimate the strength of the feedback mechanisms that contribute to the overall climate sensitivity. We use a chemistry–climate model to estimate the strength of the feedback that exists between the stratosphere and troposphere. We find that this feedback is significant, and that it is larger than previously thought.

The presence of blue-green tissues in vertebrates is a unique feature of the animal kingdom. This phenomenon is called chlorosis. The biochemical basis of chlorosis is poorly understood. Here, we describe the biochemical and molecular basis of chlorosis in anurans. We show that the presence of high biliverdin in anurans has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history. We also describe a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily. Our results provide evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis and a function for a serpin in vertebrates. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with increased tumorigenesis and metastasis. However, the mechanisms that regulate the phenotype of cancer stem cells (CSCs) in hypoxia are not well understood. Here, we show that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which demethylates m6A. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia in a HIF-dependent manner, and is required for the phenotype of CSCs. Thus, ALKBH5 is a potential therapeutic target for cancer treatment in hypoxic environments. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Parchment is a material used for making books. It is made from animal skins. The source of the skins used to make parchment is a long-standing controversy. Here, we present a method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We show that the source of parchment used to make pocket Bibles in the 13th century was not abortive or newborn animals. Instead, we show that the source was the local availability of hides of several species. This suggests that the production process allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe biotic crisis in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is still debated. The age model for the extinction is critical to understanding the extinction mechanism. Here we present a precise age model for the extinction. The age model is based on the age of a volcanic ash bed and allows us to explore the links between environmental perturbation, carbon cycle disruption, mass extinction, and recovery. The age model will be critical to evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

IBD is a group of inflammatory bowel diseases, including ulcerative colitis and Crohn’s disease. IBD is a chronic disease with no cure. The pathogenesis of IBD is complex and not fully understood. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORα deletion leads to excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Our findings provide a potential therapeutic target for IBD. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for neutralizing antibodies and vaccines. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein in the presence of the D614G mutation with the wild-type protein. We find that the mutant spike is more flexible and adopts a range of more open conformations. These changes may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent fusion. Our results suggest that the D614G mutation may increase infectivity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs. These are games in which the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every such game admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is new even for finite games. The proof also yields a characterization of the set of all ε-equilibria in terms of a simple game. This characterization is new even for finite games. The result is also new for infinite games.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life

Pressure is a powerful tool to induce chemical transformations. However, the chemical effects of pressure are not well understood. Here, we show that pressure-induced metallization is accompanied by a decrease of electronegativity and hardness. We also show that the pseudo–noble-gas configuration is achieved for Ni, Pd, and Pt. Our results are of fundamental importance for the understanding of the chemical effects of pressure. They also have important implications for the prediction of new chemical phenomena under pressure. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in some regions and decrease it in others. However, the net effect is not yet clear. We show that human ignitions and suppression can have a large influence on the future fire regime. Our results suggest that climate change may be slowed by up to 0.11 °C by 2100, but this is contingent on lower emissions scenarios. Our findings highlight the importance of fire in the climate system and the need to understand the effects of human activities on fire regimes. This is important for the management of ecosystems and the mitigation of climate change. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms that regulate the timing and quantity of nutrient delivery are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the timing and quantity of chitin provision to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in a manner that is synchronized with the host’s circadian rhythms. This regulation is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. Our results suggest that the timing of nutrient delivery may be a general mechanism used by animals to control the health of their symbionts. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Text data are ubiquitous and increasingly important. However, it is difficult to identify latent patterns in text. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. Our method is based on advances in machine learning. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data.

The Black Death, the most devastating epidemic in human history, is generally attributed to a single introduction of Yersinia pestis into Europe. However, this attribution is based on a single hypothesis. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia. Our results suggest that the Black Death was the consequence of multiple introductions of the plague bacterium into Europe. This finding challenges the prevailing paradigm of the Black Death and opens up new perspectives on the history of the plague pandemic. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web. They are also a source of food for many species of sea stars. In the past few years, a densovirus has been associated with a disease that has led to the mass mortality of sea stars. We show that this densovirus is the likely cause of the disease.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia in adults. Despite advances in therapy, the survival rate of AML patients is still poor. The IL1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We show that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We also demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects. Finally, we show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean. It is the only island in the world that is both a biodiversity hotspot and a place of origin of new human populations. The settlement history of Madagascar is still debated. Here, we present a high-resolution genomic analysis of the Malagasy population. We find that Madagascar is a unique place in the world, with a recent and sex-biased colonization from Africa and Asia. In addition, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. Our results provide a new perspective on the settlement history of Madagascar. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. These RNAs are generally considered to be “noncoding,” but a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that increases the activity of glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase. We also show that the RNA base pairs with the cadA and galE genes and that the base pairing interferes with the RNA’s ability to repress cadA and galE. These results demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has evolved to regulate metabolism. (Read more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has been a global health crisis. The development of effective vaccines and therapeutic antibodies is critical to combat the pandemic. However, the emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the efficacy of these antibodies. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach to optimize the binding affinity of antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody that is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. Our optimized antibody can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our approach can be applied to other protein molecules.
