Crop experts are the eyes and ears of farmers. They provide information on crop status that is critical for agricultural decision-making. However, the information provided by crop experts is often qualitative and subjective. Here, we show how to convert this information into a continuous probabilistic variable that can be used for quantitative analysis. We show that the resulting probabilistic variable is robust across different crops and has nation-wide validity. We also demonstrate how this information can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results show the potential of leveraging the network of “people as sensors” to improve agricultural decision-making. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that is essential for communication. It is also a highly plastic system that is modified by experience. Here we propose a model of language processing that is based on the idea that memory is supported by adaptive changes in neuronal excitability. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order and can be used to integrate information over time. Our results suggest that memory is maintained in a dynamic state that is accessed directly without cued retrieval. This mechanism is not reliant on synaptic plasticity or persistent activity. It is therefore a candidate substrate for the neural processing of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, but its response to climate change is poorly understood. We present the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types. Our results demonstrate that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important events in the evolution of life on Earth. It is also one of the most studied, but the molecular mechanisms underlying this transition remain largely unknown. Here, we present a model of the molecular evolution of plastid genomes during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. Our model suggests that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings have implications for the evolution of plastid genomes in general and for the evolution of the photosynthetic apparatus in particular. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The 2015–2017 drought in southwestern South Africa was the worst in the last century. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of this drought. This is a consequence of the strong sensitivity of the rainfall deficit to the atmospheric circulation. Our results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This is a key finding for the global climate change debate. Copyright © 2018. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the conditions under which they are formed are still not fully understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this anthropogenic quasicrystal provides a link between the formation of naturally occurring quasicrystals and the nuclear test explosions that occurred in the 20th century. The biosynthesis of chlorophyll pigments is one of the most important biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess a diiron protein. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in the isocyclic cyclase accumulate the reaction substrate. Here we show that the diiron enzyme is required for the growth of cyanobacteria and that it is required for the growth of purple phototrophic bacteria. These results indicate that the diiron enzyme is a key component of the isocyclic cyclase in oxygenic phototrophs. The evolution of the isocyclic cyclase is discussed. (Read more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroactive protein kinase ASK1 is involved in neuroinflammation. However, the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. Here, we report that ASK1 is essential for microglia/macrophage-mediated neuroinflammation. ASK1 deficiency in astrocytes also exacerbates neuroinflammation. ASK1-dependent glial cells play a critical role in the progression of neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1-targeted therapies may be a promising strategy for treating neurodegenerative diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades. In addition, the probability that precipitation deficits are also warm has increased. These findings suggest that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions. This is a significant finding because the probability of drought is increasing. The probability of drought is increasing because of human activities.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. Here, we show that behavioral flexibility is a converging target of multiple autism-risk genes. We also show that behavioral inflexibility is caused by the inability to forget. These findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and may facilitate the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

News media are a critical source of information for the public. In this work, we examine the extent to which news content is perceived as negative around the world. We find that, on average, news content is perceived as more negative than entertainment content. We also find that individual-level differences in negativity bias are substantial. These results have implications for the content of news media, and for the way in which we think about the psychology of news consumption.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis. Dysregulation of the CRAC channel can lead to a variety of diseases. Here, we report on a Stormorken-like syndrome, which is characterized by hematological abnormalities, bleeding diathesis, miosis, and tubular myopathy. We show that the STIM1 p.R304W gain-of-function mutation is responsible for this syndrome. In addition, we report on a Stormorken syndrome, which is characterized by hematological abnormalities, bleeding diathesis, and a tubular myopathy. We show that the ORAI1 p.P245L gain-of-function mutation is responsible for this syndrome. Our findings expand our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The spreading of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases. Here we show that the spreading of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is non–cell autonomous and that the spreading of aggregates is dependent on endocytosis. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1. These results suggest that the spreading of aggregates is a key element of neurodegenerative disease progression. This study provides a model for studying the mechanisms of spreading in neurodegenerative diseases. This model can be used to study the effects of drugs that inhibit the spreading of aggregates. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The immune system is a critical factor in the maintenance of health and the prevention of disease. However, the immune system can also be used by pathogens to cause disease. The immune system is also a target for therapeutic intervention. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the immunosuppressant effects of MTX and the potential for MTX to be used as a therapeutic agent. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is a metabolic disease. Cancer cells have a high demand for one-carbon units, which are essential for cell growth. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. Here we report the discovery of small-molecule dual inhibitors of human SHMT1/2. We show that these compounds are effective in cancer cell lines, and that one-carbon donor formate is a rescue agent. However, formate is a poor inhibitor of cancer cells with defective glycine import. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. The disease is caused by mutations in a variety of proteins, including superaggregation-prone proteins such as superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), the TDP-43 protein, and the FUS protein. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins. Rather, they are a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that the metastable nature of these proteins is a common feature of many neurodegenerative diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystal is designed to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including suppressed spontaneous emission, photon-mediated atom–atom interactions, and control of the atom–atom interactions by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device can be fabricated from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the evolution of the plant kingdom. The first flowering plants were aquatic plants. The oldest known aquatic flowering plants are Montsechia and Archaefructus. Montsechia is a small tree with a single stem. It is very similar to Ceratophyllum, a living aquatic plant. Montsechia is from the early Cretaceous and is the oldest known flowering plant.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in molecular biology. However, the evolution of many viruses is not well understood because of the difficulty in obtaining viral sequences from ancient remains. Here we present viral sequences from ancient remains of humans from Eurasia and Greenland. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype. These results emphasize the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Sea level is rising, and this rise is accelerating. These changes are driven by a combination of natural processes and human activities. The rate of sea level rise is determined by the balance between these two. We find that the acceleration of sea level rise is consistent with the expected climate-change signal. This result is important because it provides a direct measurement of the climate-change signal. It also provides a check on the ability of climate models to simulate this signal. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Pain is a normal part of life. It is a signal that something is wrong. As we age, we expect pain to increase. But in America today, pain is less than it was for those in midlife. This is the mystery of American pain. We show that pain is not declining with age. Instead, it is increasing with age for all adults. The increase is driven by the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity. This detailed picture of the reaction pathway is key to understanding why the natural substrate indole reacts, but not benzimidazole. The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe pathogen that causes a high mortality rate. There is no specific antiviral treatment available. Here, we show that remdesivir, a nucleotide analog, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This is the first report of remdesivir treatment in a MERS-CoV infection model. Our results support the further development of remdesivir as a potential treatment for MERS-CoV infection. This may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms that regulate the timing and quantity of nutrient delivery are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the timing and quantity of chitin provision to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in a manner that is synchronized with the host’s circadian rhythms. This regulation is necessary for the persistence of the symbiosis. We propose that this strategy is used by many animal hosts to control the activities of their associated microbial communities. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Suspension rates are high and rising in US schools. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt a more empathic mindset about discipline. This change in mindset is associated with a reduction in suspensions. The intervention is scalable and can be implemented in schools.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. Copyright © 2017. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To infect human cells, MERS-CoV must first bind to cell receptors. To determine how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first cleavages. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental degradation. The food choices of the population have a major influence on this. However, the food system is also a major contributor to health inequalities. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a university cafeteria can increase the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased by 60%. This has the potential to improve population health and the environment.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to engage the extracellular space. Here we apply quantitative proteomics to reveal how the surfaceome is remodeled in a collection of six oncogenes, including EGFR, HER2, KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a widespread call for expanding voting-by-mail programs. However, the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes have not been systematically studied. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. Our findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the pandemic.

SARS-CoV-2 is the cause of the COVID-19 pandemic. The SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein ORF8 is a rapidly evolving protein that has been proposed to interfere with the host immune response. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. This dimerization interface is unique to SARS-CoV-2 and may be important for immune suppression and evasion. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cerebral edema is a life-threatening condition. Here we report that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats. We also show that this hypoxia-induced edema is associated with increased expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. These effects could all be blocked by pretreatment with an antagonist of the CRF receptor CRFR1. We also show that, in cultured astrocytes, exogenous CRF triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε. The up-regulated cAMP/PKA signaling contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of AQP4 to enhance water influx into astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of ET-1 expression. Finally, using transfected cells, we show that transfected CRFR1 contributes to edema via transfected AQP4. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms of hypoxic cerebral edema. They also suggest a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of cerebral edema. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The world is full of associations. We want to know which ones are important. But we have to be careful. We don’t want to declare an association as important when it is not. And we don’t want to declare an association as unimportant when it is. This paper describes a way to do this.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce EC development remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can induce the formation of functional vascular ECs. Our study provides a promising approach for the generation of ECs for therapeutic purposes. This approach may also be useful for the generation of vascular networks for regenerative medicine. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK) pathway is one of the most important signaling pathways in the body. It is involved in a wide range of physiological processes, including cell proliferation, differentiation, and survival. In addition, RTKs are involved in a variety of pathological processes, including cancer. In this study, we identify two additional ligands for the RTKs anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk). We show that these ligands are essential for the development of the zebrafish iridophores. Our results establish a physiological link between these ligands and Ltk. This study provides a better understanding of the role of RTKs in development and disease. It also provides a model system for the study of RTK signaling in vivo. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

β-cell dysfunction is a major molecular basis for type 2 diabetes (T2D). Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of diabetic mice and patients with T2D. STING deficiency in β-cells caused glucose intolerance due to impaired insulin secretion. STING is required for β-cell function and is associated with nuclear factor-X1 (NF-X1). These findings establish pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for T2D. Copyright © 2017. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Influenza A viruses are the main cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. They are able to undergo genetic reassortment between their segments, which is essential for their evolution. However, the molecular mechanisms that control this process are not fully understood. Here, we identified a mechanism that favors the packaging of viral RNA segments in influenza A viruses. This mechanism is sequence dependent and involves a supramolecular network of interactions. This mechanism might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results could help to understand the evolution of this virus and its potential to cause future pandemics. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Atherosclerosis is the leading cause of death worldwide. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process involving multiple factors. The present study demonstrates that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion formation. Our findings provide a molecular mechanism for the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, human activities have increased the spatial and seasonal extent of wildfire. This expansion has increased the economic and ecological costs of wildfire. We show that human activities have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire. Our results highlight the need for increased management of human-caused wildfires.

Urban change is a major topic of urban studies. However, the mechanisms of urban change are not well understood. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We then use this method to measure changes in the physical appearances of five US cities over a 10-y period. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change. Our method can be used to study urban change in other cities and other countries. It can also be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in the future. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to chemical pesticides. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne flavivirus that causes microcephaly and other neurological complications in newborns. The current outbreak has led to a global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the growth and clearance of ZIKV within an individual are highly variable. We also show that an antiviral treatment can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load. However, the current treatment options are not effective in reducing the time to undetectable median plasma viral load. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Coral reefs are among the most valuable ecosystems on the planet. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. One of the most important environmental drivers of coral mortality is coral bleaching, a process in which corals lose their symbiotic zooxanthellae and turn white. The loss of the zooxanthellae is accompanied by a loss of the coral’s capacity to capture and use nutrients. We show that the loss of the coral’s zooxanthellae is a direct consequence of the coral’s metabolic response to heat stress. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of coral bleaching and may ultimately help us to predict the stability of the coral–algal symbiosis in response to environmental change. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier to the environment and a hub for communication with the immune system. In the presence of tumors, the epithelium becomes dysfunctional, leading to a dysbiotic microbiome and a regenerative response. This feedback loop is amplified by JNK signaling, which is activated by tumors and the dysbiotic microbiome. Our study identifies a mechanism that links tumorigenesis to the microbiome and highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our findings have implications for the development of cancer therapies and the design of microbiome-based interventions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Despite advances in treatment, the majority of patients relapse. In this study, we found that the expression of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor 1 (ROR1) is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also found that ROR1 expression is associated with breast cancer stemness. Finally, we demonstrated that targeting ROR1 with the humanized monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can improve the response to chemotherapy in a mouse model of breast cancer. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy in breast cancer. This approach may be particularly useful in patients who have developed resistance to chemotherapy. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The timing of the onset of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is a matter of debate. Here we show that a volcanic eruption series at the start of deglaciation is a plausible explanation for the changes in climate and ice sheet dynamics. The volcanic eruptions are associated with stratospheric ozone depletion, which is a plausible mechanism for the onset of deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food and livelihoods for hundreds of millions of people. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. Here, we present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that most catches come from regions with high stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the world’s poorest people. Our analysis highlights the importance of freshwater fisheries for food security and biodiversity conservation. However, the high dependence of poor populations on these resources also makes them vulnerable to degradation by overfishing and pollution. Our results highlight the need for improved management of inland fisheries to ensure their continued provision of food and ecosystem services.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The safety of aqueous Li-ion batteries is limited by the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability to regenerate is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are unable to regenerate in response to injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This discovery has implications for understanding the molecular mechanisms that control the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. Moreover, it may lead to new strategies for regenerating the CNS. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Recombination is essential for genome stability and the generation of genetic diversity. In eukaryotes, the process is initiated by the binding of proteins to specific DNA sequences. In this study, we describe the location of these binding sites in the genome of a flowering plant. We find that the distribution of binding sites is remarkably similar to that of recombination hotspots in yeast and in mice. This suggests that the initiation of recombination in eukaryotes may be conserved and ancient. Our results also reveal a surprising polarity in recombination in the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. In this species, recombination is more likely to occur near the start of genes than in their middle or end. This polarity may be a consequence of the evolutionary history of the genus Mimulus. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The resting brain is organized in networks of functionally related regions. The identification of these networks is a key step in understanding the functional architecture of the brain. Here, we used metabolic imaging to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant metabolic RSN in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow scans acquired during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during task performance, and this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This study provides a direct measure of the resting organization of the brain in health and disease. This information can be used to understand the functional architecture of the brain. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. Here we describe a second 5′ modification in yeast, a nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap. We show that NAD-mRNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. NAD-mRNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally because NAD-RNA is also found on pre-mRNAs. This 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate mRNA stability and translation.

The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) showed that intensive glucose control can prevent microvascular complications in people with diabetes. However, the long-term effects of this therapy are not fully understood. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci persist for several years during the follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (EDIC Study). These epigenetic alterations are associated with glycemia and may explain the metabolic memory observed in the EDIC Study. Our results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 is highly expressed in TNBC and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disease. The mechanisms underlying the development of the disease are not fully understood. In this study, we found that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness. This gut dysfunction is associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals. These volatiles are produced during ripening, and their content varies widely among different tomato cultivars. The biosynthesis of these volatiles is not known. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also describe a method for the biosynthesis of these compounds in plants. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor. It also opens the door to the development of improved cultivars with enhanced flavor. (Read more)

Biodiversity is a key component of ecosystem functioning. However, the impacts of climate change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning are not well understood. Here we show that changes in temperature can alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. We found that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning became steeper as temperatures deviated from ambient conditions. This result was driven by changes in the thermal tolerance curves of species, which increased the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect. Our results highlight the importance of considering the impacts of climate change on the thermal tolerance curves of species when investigating the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. This is critical for understanding the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation. It is thought to encode a map of local space, but the organization of its neurons is not well understood. Here, we used portable two-photon microscopes to record from MEC neurons in freely moving mice. We found that grid cells, which encode the spatial layout of the environment, are anatomically segregated from other neurons. This suggests that grid cells might form a distinct network. Our data also suggest that grid cells are strongly coupled among themselves but have weaker links to other neurons. These findings provide a detailed view of the organization of the MEC map of space. They may help to explain how the brain represents the environment during navigation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by environmental and internal signals. In this study, we show that the FT gene is not required for flowering of the host plant. Instead, FTs are able to move from the host to the dodder, where they interact with a dodder FD transcription factor to induce flowering. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts. The dopamine system of the brain is critical to movement and motivation. Here, we describe a specialized subsystem of the nigro–striato–nigral loop that is formed by striosomes, their axons, and dopamine-containing dendrites. These formations, here termed “striosome–dendron bouquets,” are unique in the brain. They are densely innervated by a variety of afferents and are connected to the striatum. We suggest that striosome–dendron bouquets are critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We all feel connected to others. But how do we know when we feel connected to someone? We asked people to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other predicted how connected they felt. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, the sinoatrial cells (SACSs), which are responsible for heart rate control. The SAN is also the site of the heart’s natural pacemaker potential. The heart rate is controlled by the SAN by a complex mechanism involving the heart’s electrical activity. This mechanism is not fully understood. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the heart’s electrical activity. We show that STIM1 is expressed in the sinoatrial cells and is essential for the heart’s electrical activity. Our results suggest that STIM1 is a key regulator of the heart’s electrical activity. Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder. This effect is dependent on jasmonate (JA) signaling. Our results suggest that Si and JA interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest control. The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in ether lipid metabolism. We also show that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important for the regulation of the macrophage lipidome. Our results suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of macrophage lipid metabolism.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that is essential for communication. It is also a highly plastic system that is modified by experience. Here we propose a model of language processing that is based on the idea that memory is supported by adaptive changes in neuronal excitability. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order and can be used to integrate information over time. Our results suggest that memory is not stored as a persistent depolarization but rather as a dynamic state that can be accessed directly. This mechanism is not reliant on synaptic plasticity or feedback. It is therefore a candidate substrate for the neural processing of language.

Plants are sessile organisms and are unable to move to avoid toxic substances. Thus, they are dependent on external factors for their survival. One such factor is the delivery of biomolecules to plants. Here, we report the delivery of biomolecules to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are critical for the delivery and gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful for the delivery of biomolecules to plants for their use in agriculture and other applications. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Nutrient pollution is a major threat to aquatic ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient pollution originates from small tributaries draining surrounding watersheds. However, the importance of small tributaries has been largely overlooked. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas. Our findings have important implications for the design of nutrient management strategies to protect aquatic ecosystems.

The study of chemical reactions in the presence of external forcing is of fundamental importance in chemistry and biology. Here, we study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. Our results suggest that the extremization of external forcing may be a general principle underlying the dynamics of complex chemical systems. This article is protected by copyright. The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Ab encephalitis is associated with changes in the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We then show that these changes can be explained by a dynamic model of the cortical microcircuit. Finally, we show that these changes are sufficient to induce paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in a mouse model of the disease. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab. They also suggest that the same circuit changes may be responsible for the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in other autoimmune encephalitis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood. This is mainly due to the lack of proxy records that can capture such events. Here, we present a multiproxy approach to reconstruct a global warming event that occurred ∼304 Ma. We show that the event was associated with a decrease in biodiversity and a doubling of atmospheric CO2. The event was likely triggered by a large organic matter burial event. Earth system modeling indicates that the event was associated with enhanced nutrient fluxes and thermocline stratification. This study highlights the importance of organic matter burial in triggering abrupt climate change. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation. Certification is the most common tool used to meet corporate and government commitments to reduce this deforestation. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has not been well studied. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia. Nevertheless, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Our results suggest that certification is not yet having the intended conservation benefits. We recommend that certification be expanded to forested regions, that strict requirements be imposed to avoid all peat, and that certification be linked to routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss. These changes are necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Copyright © 2018. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The exocyst complex is essential for the final steps of exocytosis. Its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases. However, the study of its regulation is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes in human cells. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. This article is protected by copyright. Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology. In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus. In others, multiple loci interact to produce more than two genotypic sexes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that multiple alleles can produce a modular interplay of sex linkage and sex limitation, resulting in a variety of secondary sexual characteristics. These results suggest that multiple alleles can produce a higher-order polymorphism in secondary sexual characteristics. Our findings have implications for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by multiple sources of reactive oxygen species. The retina is also a site of iron accumulation, which can lead to the formation of reactive oxygen species-generating adducts of vitamin A. We show that iron levels in the retina can influence the formation of these adducts and their photochemical degradation. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. They also suggest that iron chelation may be beneficial in the treatment of age-related macular degeneration. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end. We show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, are an exception to this rule. They are characterized by a high degree of specialization, and have evolved to capture different prey types. Our results suggest that specialization is linked to the evolution of morphological changes in the tentacles, and that shifts between prey types are linked to shifts in the morphology, mode of evolution, and evolutionary correlations of the tentacles and their nematocysts. Our findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The human hand is a remarkable adaptation that has been the subject of intense study for more than 200 y. However, the evolution of the modern human hand is poorly understood because of a gap in the fossil record between 800,000 and 1.8 My. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of the human hand. The fossil also suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. These findings have implications for our understanding of the evolution of the human hand and its role in tool use. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is a metabolic disease. Cancer cells have a high demand for one-carbon units, which are essential for cell growth. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. Here we report the discovery of small-molecule dual inhibitors of human SHMT1/2. We show that these compounds are effective in cancer cell lines, and that one-carbon donor formate is a rescue agent. However, formate is a poor inhibitor of cancer cells with defective glycine import. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer. The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. In this study, we show that deforestation is having a negative impact on people’s diets in rural Tanzania. This is a significant finding given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition. Our findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are a critical resource for meeting nutrition and environmental goals.

Modern agriculture is the most productive system in history, but it is also the most damaging to the environment. The use of farm machinery has greatly increased the productivity of agriculture, but it has also increased the weight of vehicles, which has led to subsoil compaction. We show that subsoil compaction is widespread and has increased over time. We also show that the weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth. This suggests that prehistoric animals may have caused subsoil compaction, which may have had a negative impact on the productivity of the ecosystem. Our results suggest that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This article is protected by copyright.
